Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's decision concerning state protection was unreasonable
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to abuse by her stepfather; she did not file a complaint with authorities after reaching adulthood
Decision_Outcome: RPD's decision was reasonable; application for judicial review dismissed
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to domestic abuse and lack of state protection
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard as defined in Dunsmuir
Assessment_Factor: Capability of foreign state to protect its citizens
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide clear and convincing evidence
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence of independent judiciary and enforcement of laws against violence
Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Basis: Claim of inadequate state protection in home country
Evidence_Assessed: Lack of complaints to authorities; existence of functional legal system
Relief_Sought: Overturning of RPD's negative decision on refugee protection
Governing_Rule: Presumption that foreign state can protect its citizens unless rebutted by clear and convincing evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to report abuse to authorities; insufficient evidence of state incapacity
Cause_Description: Applicant claimed she faced abuse and her home country could not protect her
Evidence_Handling: RPD considered documentary evidence and applicantâ€™s lack of engagement with legal authorities
Evidence_Issues: Lack of credible, corroborating evidence on state protection failure
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed functioning judiciary and rule of law in home country
Decision_Rationale: No clear and convincing evidence to rebut presumption of state protection capability
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence to establish failure of state protection
